_header: Sir Clerk of Oxenford our Host said
_description: Geoffrey Chaucer, the Clerk’s Prologue of the Canterbury Tales —56 lines in rhyming couplets.

BodArcSelB14.First Lines:
SIr clerke of Oxonford oure ost saydeye ride as quoy & stille
                    as a mayde…
BodArcSelB14.Last Lines:
…save he wol conveye his matiereBut this is the tale which ye
                    shal hiere
BodArcSelB14.Attributed Title:
…And next folwith / the Clerke of Oxonford is prolog (f.
                        65v); the clerkes prolog (RT); Here endith the clerke of Oxonford
                    his prolog… (f. 66)

BodBar20.First Lines:
Sir Clerk of Oxenford oure Ost seideȜe ride as koy and stille
                    as a maide…
BodBar20.Last Lines:
…Saue þat he wol conueien his materBut þis is
                    þe tale whiche ȝe may here

Bod414.First Lines:
[S]ir Clerk of Oxford oure host saidye ride as stille and coy as
                    doþ a maid…
Bod414.Last Lines:
…Saue that ye wil conceyue his matiereBut this is the tale
                    which ye may here
Bod414.Attributed Title: The prolog of the Clerk of Oxenford (f. 89v)

Bod686.First Lines:
Sir clerk of Oxenforde oure host seydeye ride as koy and stylle as
                    doth a Mayde…
Bod686.Last Lines:

                    which þat ye may here
Bod686.Attributed Title:
…And begynneþ / þe prohemium of þe clerke of
                    Oxonforddes Tale (f. 98v); Clerke (RT)

BodHatDon1.First Lines:

BodHatDon1.Last Lines:

                    as ye shal here
BodHatDon1.Attributed Title:
…And next begynneth the / Prolog of the Clerk of Oxenford (f.
                        164v); The Clerk (RT); Here endeth the prolog of the Clerk…
                    (f. 165)

Alnwick455.First Lines:
Sir Clerk of Oxinforth our hoost seydeyee ryde as still as it were
                    a maide…
Alnwick455.Last Lines:
…And now woll I procede in my matereThis is my tale as yee
                    shal here
Alnwick455.Attributed Title:
Here begynnyth the Clerk of Oxinforth his prologg (f.
                    116v)

GULHun197.First Lines:
Sir Clerke of Oxenford oure Ooste saideYe ride as stille and coye
                    as dooth a mayde…
GULHun197.Last Lines:
…Saf he wole conueye his matierBut this is the tale that ye
                    shal here
GULHun197.Note:
On f. 102vb, in rubic, the scribe has written:
                        ‘Orate pro salute animarum Galfridi Spirleng Ciuis Norwici
                        Courtholder Clerici Maioratus & dicte Comitatus ac Thome Spirleng filij
                        sui qui scribendo hunc librum compleuerunt mense Ianuariij anno domini
                            Millesimo CCCCmolxxvjto quo tempore dictus
                        Galfridus quasi quinquaginta et dictus Thomas quasi Sexdecim etatis
                        extiterunt annorum’. This is followed in the text ink by:
                    ‘This writyng is drawn for the book of Canterbury is not yet ended and
                    therfor these woords arn writen yet folwyng immediatly’. In the same
                    column, but above the previous two passages and also in rubric is: ‘Be it
                    remembred that the tale of the Clerk of Oxenford and the ta // le of the Chanons
                    yoman folwen immediat // li in the next leef’.
GULHun197.Attributed Title:
Here begynneth the prologe of þe Clerk of / Oxenford (f.
                        103ra); The Clerk of Oxenford (RT); Here endeth þe
                    prologus… (f. 103rb)

BNangl39.First Lines:
Syr Clerk of Oxenford oure host saideye ryde als coy & stille
                    as dooþ a mayde…
BNangl39.Last Lines:
…sauf that he wil conioyne his materebut this is the tale
                    which þat yee shal here
BNangl39.Attributed Title:
…& iam incipti / prologus fabule Clerici Oxonie
                    (f. 31ra); Explicit prohemium fabule Cle / rici Oxonie…
                    (f. 31va)

TokyoTak22.First Lines:
SIr Clerk of Oxinford owre Oste saydeȝe ryden as style and coy
                    as doth a maydeWere newe spowsyd syttyng at a bordeThis day ne herde I
                    of your mouth a worde…
TokyoTak22.Last Lines:
…Saue þat he wold conveyn his materBut this is þe
                    tale wheche þat ȝe schul here
TokyoTak22.Attributed Title:
Here begynneth the prolog of [the Clerk fabula?(smudged)] of Oxenford (f.
                    1, rubric); Explicit prohemium (f. 2)
TokyoTak22.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.  
             The Clerk’s Tale, a Six-Text Print from 6 MSS not containing the
                Pardoner’s Tale.
The Chaucer Society
         Series 1, no. 92. London: Trübner, 1899.

TokyoTak24.First Lines:
Sir clerk of Oxenforde oure oost saideYe ride as coy and stille as
                    a maide…
TokyoTak24.Last Lines:
…Saue that he wol conueye his matereBut this is his tale wich
                    that ye may hiere
TokyoTak24.Attributed Title:
…Et Incipit Prologus Clerici / Oxonie cuius fabula est de /
                        Grisilde mitissima (f. 98v, rubric); Hic desinit Prologus
                        Clerici Oxonie… (f. 99, rubric)

Bodmer48.First Lines:
Sir Clerk of Oxford our host seidye ride as stil & coy as a
                    maid…
Bodmer48.Last Lines:
…Saue þat ye wil conceyue his materBut þis is the
                    tale which ye mai her
Bodmer48.Attributed Title: The Clerkis prolog of Oxenford (f. 101, rubric)
